 Rice Wants It--But in Draft Form
 
 Political associates of Secretary of State Condi Rice are stirring the 2008 presidential pot on her behalf. While she takes the high road, they're pushing her name out there. "She definitely wants to be president," said one. But, the friend added, Rice isn't planning on quitting to run. "She wants to be drafted," he said.
 
 http://www.usnews.com/usnews/politics/whispers/articles/050530/30whisplead.htm

 No, but she doesn't need to. If she got only 35-40% of the black vote that would be a quantum improvement from the 90% of the guaranteed black vote for the Democratic candidate.  Actually, this isn't all that hard to do. What you or anyone can do is to go to the U.S. Congress site and look down the list of the 535 senators and representatives to arrive a legitimate contenders. And then it is merely a process of elimination. Then you also look at the 50 U.S. governors. Same thing. 
 
 On the Democratic site it appears that Hillary has a lock unless she is taken down by a scandal. Then there is the possibility of John Kerry but that is unlikely. The more likely contender would be John Edwards. The VP can be almost anyone who has kept their nose clean and won't do damage to the ticket. Obama would fit that criteria. Mary Landrieu also comes to mind. Evan Bayh is another. And of course there is always Bill Richardson. And an up and comer would be Governor Mark Warner of Virginia.
 
 On the Republican side, there are the usual suspects. Senator John McCain, Senator George Allen, Governor Bill Owens, former Mayor Rudy Guilliani, Senator Elizabeth Dole, Senator Bill Frist, Senator Chuck Hagel, Senator Kay Bailey Hutchinson, Governor Jeb Bush. Cheney is he wants it and if he did, he would receive the nomination. Roy Blunt could be the VP candidate. Bobby Jindal is a wild card. And finally there is the Rice wild card for either Prez or VP.
 
 Not a single member of the House made the cut for president.
 
 That's it. The above list is complete. You will find the next President "X" in the list I have provided. 
 
 I could see a Hillary/Warner ticket. And I could see a Cheney/Bush ticket. Those would be very strong tickets on either side.
 
 If Cheney does not choose to run, then it will be a slugfest between McCain and the challengers but Hillary has it locked up on the Democratic side.
 
 BTW, I have another Mr "X" that I would personally vote for but it would require a party change to accomplish that. He would make a splendid president but it won't happen.
Missouri Mule

 Hillary would top out about 45% or so. Getting that other 5% would be exceedingly tough. If she should not get enough of the black vote she loses and then it is President McCain. 
 
 BTW, I haven't heard anyone argue with my list. In any event, I positively, absolutely, unequivocally can state that my list is complete. The next president will come from that list.  McCain is a good choice, it's a shame Republicans weren't smart enough to nominate him in 2000. As for the future of the party in 2008, I'd say a lot depends on the conditions in Iraq and our economic health when the time comes. The multi-billion dollar advertising campaign aimed at promoting democracy in the Middle East using American troops will only captivate the voting public for so long. A recent poll on CBS reinforces that the majority of Americans don't think Bush shares the same priorities as they do regarding the economy, social security, and the war in Iraq. I know, I know, you don't think much of CBS, find another poll to dispute the findings.
 http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/05/25/opinion/polls/main697825.shtml

 Sorry, if I gave you the impression I was being biased. I've been following politics since 1948. There is really nothing new under the sun.
